name: 朴維鎮
objective: This course is an introduction to statistical computing and will be taught in R. R is widely used not only in engineering, but also in sciences, medicine, biology, physics, and business. It is assumed students have exposure to basic statistics and knowledge of calculus (i.e., differential and integral calculus). The main focus of the class will be on statistical programming, graphics, and elementary optimization in R. Students will cover various statistical methods such as estimation, hypothesis test, ANOVA, regression analysis, design of experiments, and statistical process control.
schedule:
Week 1　　Introduction to probability distribution, sampling distribution, and estimation
Week 2　　Decision making for a single sample – Estimation, hypothesis testing, inference on the mean of a population
Week 3　　Decision making for a single sample – Inference on the variance of a normal population, inference on a population proportion, goodness of fit test
Week 4　　Decision making for two samples – Inference on the means of two populations, paired t-test
Week 5　　Decision making for two samples – Inference on the ratio of variances of two normal populations, inference on two population proportions
Week 6　　Simple linear regression
Week 7　　Multiple linear regression
Week 8　　Other aspects of regression
Week 9　　Midterm exam (In-Class, 1 Cheat Sheet, Calculator)
Week 10　　Factorial design, replication, center points
Week 11　　Blocking, confounding, fractional factorial designs
Week 12　　Response surface methods and designs
Week 13　　Factorial experiments with more than two levels
Week 14　　Introduction to control charts
Week 15　　X-bar and R control chart
Week 16　　Control charts for individual measurements, process capability, control chart performance
Week 17　　Attributes control charts, measurement systems capability
Week 18　　Final exam (In-Class, 1 Cheat sheet, Calculator)
Not covers all parts of the course, but covers only what has been discussed after the second midterm.
